data.title: Timeline: Australian involvement in Afghanistan
data.meta_description: Australian forces have been active in Afghanistan in various roles since the war's inception in 2001.
data.text:
Australian forces have been active in Afghanistan in various roles since the war's inception in 2001.

The war has cost the lives of 40 Australian soldiers, and more than $7.5 billion.

Now, Prime Minister Tony Abbott has announced that the last Australian troops have left Uruzgan Province.

Take a look back at Australia's involvement in Afghanistan.

October 2001

The invasion of Afghanistan begins in response to the deadly September 11 terrorist attacks in the United States.

Late 2001: Phase one

The Australian contribution to the war, dubbed Operation Slipper, begins with the deployment of troops in an initial offensive against the Taliban.

The deployment includes a Special Forces Task Group and two Air Force aircraft, which provide support for coalition operations.

The Special Forces troops are involved in the establishment of the Coalition's first Forward Operating Base (Camp Rhino), south-west of Kandahar.

They are also involved in the capture of Kandahar International Airport in December 2001.

December 2002

Australia's initial commitment in Afghanistan concludes and the Special Forces Task Group is withdrawn.

September 2005: Phase two

A Special Forces Task Group is re-deployed to Afghanistan. The group consists of crew from the Special Air Services Regiment, the 4th Battalion, the Royal Australian Regiment, the Incident Response Regiment and logistic support personnel.

The group is equipped with heavily-modified land rovers, as well as Bushmaster mobility vehicles.

Two Chinook helicopters are also deployed to support the taskforce.

September 2006: Phase three

The Special Forces Task Group is withdrawn from Afghanistan and the first of four reconstruction task forces is deployed to Uruzgan Province.

The Australians work as part of the Dutch-led Provincial Reconstruction Team.

Those on the ground include protective elements from the 5th/7th Battalion, the Royal Australian Regiment and the 2nd Cavalry Regiment.

They are based at Forward Operating Base Ripley, outside of Tarin Kot.

April 2007

A 200-strong Special Operations Task Group is deployed to support the Reconstruction Task Force. The new group includes a Commando company-group, elements of the Special Air Services Regiment and a combat services support team.

In addition to radar crews, logistics and intelligence officers, and security personnel, it brings the number of Australian personnel in Afghanistan to 950 by mid-2007.

There are further small increases to 1,000 in mid-2008, 1,100 in early 2009 and 1,550 in mid-2009.

Early 2009

As part of the Australian mission to mentor and train Afghan troops, a number of Operational Mentoring and Liaison Teams are embedded into Afghan National Army battalions in Uruzgan.

Consequently, the Reconstruction Task Force was renamed the Mentoring and Reconstruction Task Force.

The task force's numbers get a boost in May 2009.

January 2009

Trooper Mark Donaldson becomes the first Australian in 40 years to be presented with the Victoria Cross, the nation's highest gallantry medal.

Trooper Donaldson had exposed himself to enemy fire to protect injured Australian troops during an ambush in 2008, and also saved the life of an Afghan interpreter.

February 2010

A modest Australian force remains in Afghanistan, involved in counter-insurgency operations in Uruzgan in conjunction with Dutch and other coalition forces.

The Mentoring and Reconstruction Task Force is again renamed, this time to the Mentoring Task Force.

The group's numbers are boosted, and included infantry and cavalry elements, as well as engineers and aviators.

A further 800 Australian logistic personnel are also based in the Middle East in support of Operation Slipper, but are located outside of Afghanistan.

August 2010

Command of the Provincial Reconstruction Team is passed to Australian and US forces after Dutch troops withdraw from the country.

May 2011

Two Australian soldiers die in what Air Chief Marshal Angus Houston describes as a "very bad day" in Aghanistan.

One is killed when an Australian Army Chinook helicopter crashes during a resupply operation in Zabul Province.

The other died after being shot by an Afghan National Army soldier with whom he was serving on guard duty at a patrol base in the Chora Valley.

October 2011

Three Australians are killed and seven injured after an Afghan ally turns his gun against the Australians. An Afghan interpreter is also killed.

August 2012

Five Australian soldiers are killed in two separate incidents in Afghanistan, our worst day in combat since the Vietnam War.

Three Australian soldiers were killed by a man in an Afghan army uniform in a 'green on blue' attack at a base in Uruzgan Province, and two others were killed in a helicopter crash.

Prime Minister Julia Gillard rejects calls to respond to the deaths by bringing troops home early.

November 2012

The Australian military withdraws from operating bases in Uruzgan Province and hands control to the Afghan military.

January 2013

Defence Minister Stephen Smith announces that Australia is planning an earlier handover of security in Uruzgan Province to Afghan forces.

March 2013

Defence Force Minister Stephen Smith announces the base at Tarin Kot will close at end of the year.

December 2013

Prime Minister Tony Abbott announces that the last Australian troops have now left Uruzgan Province.

Around 400 military personnel will remain in Afghanistan in training and support roles mostly in the capital Kabul and Kandahar.

The Australian Government will also provide $100 million a year to help fund Afghanistan's defence forces.
